subSubSection.paragraph: Description. Le: 4.4–6.25 mm, Wi: 3.4–4.8 mm, Lp: 1.6–2.25 mm, Wp: 2.7–3.55 mm, Le/Wi: 1.20–1.35, Wp/Lp ratio: 1.50–1.66. Body from short–oval to oval, males slightly stouter than females.

Eyes very large, gena obsolete ( fig. 21 ). Clypeus broad, approximately 1.3 times as wide as long. Clypeal grooves fine but well marked, in most populations in basal 2/3 length of clypeus running close to margin of eye then converging in obtuse angle or arch, in populations from extreme west and extreme east of range clypeal grooves run close to margin of eye only in basal half then converging in obtuse angle, surface of clypeus from slightly to strongly convex, the most convex clypeus has population from Cameroon and bassin of
Congo
, the less convex populations from extreme east. Surface of clypeus microreticulate, from slightly alutaceous to slightly shiny with few very small, setose punctures. Labrum minutely emarginate to 1/6 length. Antennae stout, segments 9–10 slightly transverse. Length ratio of antennal segments: 100:59:76:76:65:59:56:53:56:59:103. Segment 3 approximately 1.3 times as long as segment 2 and as long as segment 4.

Prosternum moderately broad in the middle, moderately expanded apically, area between coxa flat but with more or less developed median groove, surface from regular to slightly obliquely wrinkled on sides with several small hairy punctures, expanded apex not or slightly convex with slightly irregular surface and few coarse, hairy punctures.
Claws with small basal tooth.

Distribution. Widespread species, known from West , Central and East Africa, south to Zambia ( fig. 2 ). In forest regions of western and central Africa predominates stripped nominotypical form ( figs 31–33 ), in arid sub- Saharan Region and eastern Africa predominates unicolorous form ab.
baumanni
( fig. 39 ).

Remarks. One of the most widely distributed and common African cassids, very variable in body shape and colour pattern. Generally, in Central Africa in wet habitats predominates vittate form ( figs 31–33 ), while in sub- Saharan Region and eastern Africa in dry habitats predominates uniformly yellow form ( fig. 39 ) but sometimes within vittate populations occur specimens of unicolorous form. Specimens from western part of range are usually stouter, with more acute humeri than specimens from eastern part of range. Clypeus in western populations is much more convex than in eastern forms, although eastern populations have much more impressed clypeal lines. The relation among various forms of
Ch. aubei
needs genetic studies in the field and in laboratory conditions. Perhaps the taxon is a group of sibling species with partly overlapping characters, or its polymorphism has a partly geographic character. Dried museum specimens do not allow to verify this hypothesis. Thus, we treated all forms of
Ch. aubei
-complex as a single polymorphic species. On the other hand, several uniformly yellow taxa described from eastern and southern part of central Africa are very close to particular populations of
Ch. aubei
and their specific status is also doubtful.We have conserved species status for most of them because examined material of these taxa is not as rich in specimens as
Ch. aubei
. Their relationships to
Ch. aubei
also need genetic studies.

Spaeth (1924) suggested that
Ch. semivittata sensu Weise, 1896
is not conspecific with
C. semivittata Boheman, 1855
, and proposed for it a new substitute name
Ch. weisei Spaeth, 1924
. We have examined specimens preserved in ZMHU and identified by Weise as
Ch. semivittata
and in our opinion they really belong to a different aberration than specimens named as
semivittata
by Boheman (1855) . On the other hand, both represent variations of the extremely variable
Ch. aubei (Boh.)
. Thus, the name
Ch. weisei
is a junior synonym of
Ch. aubei
. Maculate form was described as
Ch. aubei
ab. dissoluta ( figs 40–42 ) but vittate, maculate and uniformly yellow forms often occur simultaneously in one locality thus we treated
Ch. aubei
ab. dissoluta as simple synonym of
Ch. aubei
. Maculate forms predominate in southern part of range of this wide-spread and variable taxon.

The typical vittate form of
Ch. aubei
( figs 31, 32 ) is very similar to untypical form of
Ch. quadriguttata
( figs 105, 106 ) with regular elytral stripes, but in
Ch. aubei
inner margin of lateral stripes is always regular while in
Ch. quadriguttata
the margin in mid length is at least slightly bent towards the suture. Form of
Ch. aubei
with thin lateral stripes not connected on suture ( figs 34, 35 ) is similar to
Ch. circe
( fig. 48 ) but differs in fine elytral punctation with interspaces in lateral rows mostly twice as wide as puncture diameter while in
Ch. circe
punctation of elytra is coarse and dense with punctures in lateral rows almost touching each other. Small specimens of
Ch. aequinoctialis
are similar to the vittate form of
Ch. aubei
( figs 24, 25 , 31, 32 ) but differ in yellow clypeus and black marginal interval while in
Ch. aubei
clypeus is black and marginal interval yellow ( figs 19 , 21 ). Spotted form of
Ch. aubei
(described as ab. dissoluta ) is similar to the group of species with pattern formed by rows of separate black spots:
Ch. nigrostillata
,
Ch. tanganikana
and
Ch. tessellata
( figs 40–42 , 83, 84 , 96–101 ) but they differ in presence of at least two pairs of black spots behind scutellum while in
Ch. aubei
no spot occurs in sutural area; at most along the suture runs a more or less regular black vitta. The most similar pattern to spotted form of
Ch. aubei
has
Ch. picturata
( figs 94, 95 ) but it differs in more elongate body (length/width ratio 1.48–1.49 vs. 1.29–1.32), base of elytra only slightly wider than pronotum and strongly declivous explanate margin of elytra. Completely yellow form of
Ch. aubei
(described as
Ch. baumanni
) is very similar to two other yellow species with black clypeus and short-oval to subcircular body:
Ch. observabilis
and
Ch. flavipennis
( figs 39 , 56–61 , 111, 112 ). Identification of these three forms needs comparison with series of properly identified specimens. In
Ch. aubei
clypeal grooves run close to margin to eyes and on top of clypeal triangle converging in obtuse angle while in two relatives clypeal grooves form regular triangle with sharp top thus between the triangle and inner margin of eyes runs well visible, convex fold often paler coloured than the clypeal triangle. Of these three similar forms
Ch. aubei
ab.
baumanni
has the most convex clypeus, especially in western populations the convexity is very high while in both relatives the clypeus is flat or only moderately convex.

Types examined. Holotype of
Cassida aubei
: “Celebes [sic!]” “corr. Calabar” (NRS).
